intro: Hymenocoleus scaphus, commonly known as the bladderwort, is a small aquatic plant belonging to the family Lentibulariaceae. It is characterized by its unique bladder-like structures called vesicles, which are used to trap small aquatic organisms. The plant typically grows in still or slow-moving freshwater habitats, such as ponds and ditches. Its leaves are usually small and arranged in whorls around the stem. Hymenocoleus scaphus plays a role in aquatic ecosystems by contributing to nutrient cycling and providing habitat for microorganisms.
